p.s: In the following the formal and poetic devices, thatShakespeare uses to illustrate and to intensify his view, are going to be analysed.
Sonnet 138 consists out of three quatrains and a couplet being a typical Shakespearean sonnet form.
Additionally an alternating rhyme scheme (abab cdcd efef) is used in the quatrains in the cabinet rhymes in a gg constellation.
The rhythm is clearly aan iambic pentameter, which supports a heartbeat-like structure and is typical for a Shakespearean sonnet.
the Volta happens in line 9 But, where are the speaker questions the necessarity of those lies and then realizes the consequences.
Now moving on to poetic devices, the personification speaking tongue (l. 7) catches the exe of the reader.
It gives the impression of the speaker not giving his loved one the full responsibility of her lies.
In addition the reader gets the vivid image of a self speaking tongue, which employs a rather odd feeling inside the reader.
The two rhetorical questions But wherefore says [...] And wherefore say not [...] (ll. 9f.) mark the turning point, the Volta of the sonnet.
They show the indecisiveness of the speaker in an inviting way for the reader to also think about this topic more actively.
At this point the speaker is questioning the whole construct of love which is based on the lies in his case.
A feeling of sadness and helplessness is conveyed towards the reader.
Furthermore the anaphora Wherefore, Wherefore (ll. 9f.) supports the situation the speaker is in already.
Paired with the rhetorical questions it is clear that the speaker questions his love and does not understand why the lies have to keep on going.
The inner conflict is brought directly to the reader, which strengthens the feelings of sadness and helplessness.
The personification loves best habit is in seeming trust (l. 11) gives love a rather critical and malicious connotation.
Love you seen here as a tricky feeling, which does not always involve the truth but can fake truth and trust.
As a conclusion one could say that the authorShakespeare intensified his view on love being still love even though it is based on lies.
